thread.title: Fed Policy 'Bordering on Criminal': Sun Micro Ex-CEO Scott McNealy
thread.title_full: Fed Policy 'Bordering on Criminal': Sun Micro Ex-CEO Scott McNealy

title: Fed Policy 'Bordering on Criminal': Sun Micro Ex-CEO Scott McNealy
text:
Women More Likely to Adopt Mobile Trading Technology Than Men 
McNealy, who helped start Sun Microsystems more than 30 years ago, is one of the more prominent Republicans in Silicon Valley, an area that has been thought of primarily as left-leaning in its social and financial views. 
The discussion comes at a time when former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke -- who cut the federal funds rate to its current level and enacted several rounds of quantitative easing -- is out promoting his new book, The Courage to Act: A Memoir of a Crisis and Its Aftermath. In an interview on CNBC this morning, Bernanke said there was no reason to rush to raise interest rates . 
Now 60, the outspoken McNealy believes part of the reason that we've seen the high valuation on some of the private technology companies is due to the government. 
"The government keeps printing money and keeps deficit spending in a race to the bottom, and all that does is devalue any earnings or savings denominated in dollars," McNealy said. "People are trying to figure out where to put money now, and with bond rates so low, they have to put it in equities. We have the lowest labor participation rate in 40 years. We're running at so far below capacity and people are looking to put their money in stuff that has some upside." 
An example of the valuation jump in tech: Uber , founded in 2009, is the fastest private company to reach the $50 billion valuation mark, surpassing Facebook , which reached the mark after seven years . 
The Federal Reserve, led by Chair Janet Yellen, recently announced it was keeping interest rates at an all-time low, where they have been since 2008.
